titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Martha Bradstreet Papers
titlestmt.author: by Matthew D. Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:18

did.unittitle: Martha Bradstreet papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (3 boxes, including 2 oversize boxes) + 23 broadside folders)
did.abstract: The papers consist chiefly of handwritten copies of maps, survey reports, and other legal documents related to litigation by Martha Bradstreet to gain title to land throughout the Mohawk River Valley in New York State. The land, including portions of Cosby's Manor and Utica, was originally the property of Major General John Bradstreet (1714-1774), the stepfather of her father, Samuel Bradstreet. The papers served as evidence for litigation by Martha Bradstreet against owners and tenants of the land. Survey reports and maps in the collection document landownership in the regions, as well as partitions and subdivisions made during the early nineteenth century within the Mohawk River Valley communities, especially in Utica, as well as Deerfield, Masonville, and Tompkins. The papers include a holograph manuscript of Bradstreet's An Offering at the Altar of Truth (1827). It details thirty-five cases she brought in federal courts and the unfavorable rulings made by Justice Alfred Conkling (1789-1874) of United States District Court for the Northern District of New York. A small amount of correspondence includes letters and draft letters pertaining to her litigation and personal letters from her friend Clarissa "Clara" Bartlett Gregory Catlin (1807-1845).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the William Reese Company on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2009.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Martha Bradstreet Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Martha Bradstreet Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The descriptions of material in this collection were chiefly repurposed from identifications provided by the dealer.

bioghist.head: Martha Bradstreet (1780-1871)
bioghist.p: Martha Bradstreet was born on the island of Antigua in the West Indies. Her father, Samuel Bradstreet (died 1784), named her after his sister, Martha Bradstreet (died 1782). She married Matthew Codd from Ireland in 1799 and divorced him in 1816. Their marriage produced five children, Elizabeth Catherine (later Bennett), Sarah Mary Anne (later Sterling), Eleanor Cloney, John Bradstreet, and Edward Livius (born circa 1809). Through acts in the New York State Assembly, she regained her birth name in 1817 and applied the surname of Bradstreet to her children in March 1818.

Martha Bradstreet inherited land in the Mohawk River Valley of New York through the estates of her father, her namesake, and aunts, Agatha Bradstreet Evans (died 1794) and Elizabeth Bradstreet Livius (died 1795). Most of the land originally accrued through the estates of her step-grandfather, Major General John Bradstreet (1714-1774) and her grandmother, Mary Aldridge Bradstreet (died 1782). However, poorly drafted deeds of sales created uncertain titles to a portion of the land. The terms of the estate of Elizabeth Bradstreet Livius further complicated Martha Bradstreet's land claims because she had married without the approval of the estate's executor. Bradstreet subsequently discovered that much of the land she inherited from her aunt Martha was sold by the estate's executor, Charles Gould (1726-1806) through his son and attorney, Edward Goold (Gould). During the early nineteenth century she pursued litigation to cancel the land sales and gain title to the properties designated for her in the bequests. In 1831, the United States Supreme Court denied her claim to portions land in Cosby's Manor, a tract of land in and around Utica, New York, in James Jackson, Ex Dem. of Martha Bradstreet, v. Henry Huntington , 30 U.S. 5 Pet. 402 (1831).
Bradstreet continued to pursue her land claims in communities throughout the Mohawk River Valley until her death in Bennettsville, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist chiefly of handwritten copies of maps, survey reports, and other legal documents related to litigation by Martha Bradstreet to gain title to land throughout the Mohawk River Valley in New York State. The land, including portions of Cosby's Manor and Utica, was originally the property of Major General John Bradstreet (1714-1774), the stepfather of her father, Samuel Bradstreet. The papers served as evidence for litigation by Martha Bradstreet against owners and tenants of the land. Survey reports and maps in the collection document landownership in the regions, as well as partitions and subdivisions made during the early nineteenth century within the Mohawk River Valley communities, especially in Utica, as well as Deerfield, Masonville, and Tompkins. The papers include a holograph manuscript of Bradstreet's An Offering at the Altar of Truth (1827). It details thirty-five cases she brought in federal courts and the unfavorable rulings made by Justice Alfred Conkling (1789-1874) of United States District Court for the Northern District of New York. A small amount of correspondence includes letters and draft letters pertaining to her litigation and personal letters from her friend Clarissa "Clara" Bartlett Gregory Catlin (1807-1845).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: Series I. Maps, Legal Documents, and Writings, circa 1750-1877. Series II. Correspondence, 1837-1854. Each series is arranged chronologically in this guide, while materials are physically arranged by size and then chronologically.

controlaccess.subject: Real property -- New York (State) -- New York

arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically in this finding aid, materials are physically arranged by size and then chronologically..

Correspondence
Clarissa "Clara" Bartlett Gregory Catlin (1807-1845) to Martha Bradstreet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three letters that document their friendship as well as debts that she and her husband, American painter and author George Catlin (1796-1872), owe Bradstreet, and vice versa. A letter mentions portraits Catlin offered Lewis Beck, professor of geology at Rutgers University. A promissory note for five dollars from Bradstreet to George Catlin accompanies the letters.

did.unittitle: Martha Bradstreet to "Sir"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents her journey from Albany, New York, to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

did.unittitle: Martha Bradstreet to Canal Appraisers of the State of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A draft letter that details her claim for damages incurred to her property by the Erie Canal in Frankfort, New York

did.unittitle: Martha Bradstreet to stock holders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A draft letter that details her property claims to stockholders of an unidentified construction project on Lot No. 90 of Cosby's Manor, New York

did.unittitle: Martha Bradstreet to Henry Augustus Muhlenberg (1823-1854)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Details her continuing litigation and news of shared acquaintances. Muhlenberg died on January 9, 1854, so Bradstreet consequently did not send the letter.
